getStartOfWeek.desc: Returns the start of the week based on the passed in arguments

weekdays.desc: The normal weekdays array looks like this `[0,1,2,3,4,5,6]` where 0=Sunday, 1=Monday, etc. A week that starts on Monday, would look like this: `[1,2,3,4,5,6,0]` and a 5-day workweek would look like this: `[1,2,3,4,5]`

today.desc: A timestamp object that represents 'today' or a specified point in time. If passed in, then the relative information to the start-of-week timestamp object will be updated

returns.desc: A timestamp object representing the start of the week

getEndOfWeek.desc: Returns the end of the week based on the passed in arguments

weekdays.desc: The normal weekdays array looks like this `[0,1,2,3,4,5,6]` where 0=Sunday, 1=Monday, etc. A week that starts on Monday, would look like this: `[1,2,3,4,5,6,0]` and a 5-day workweek would look like this: `[1,2,3,4,5]`

today.desc: A timestamp object that represent 'today' or a specified point in time. If passed in, then the relative information to the end-of-week timestamp object will be updated

returns.desc: A timestamp object representing the end of the week

getStartOfMonth.desc: Returns the start of the month based on the passed in timestamp object

returns.desc: A timestamp object representing the start of the month

getEndOfMonth.desc: Returns the end of the month based on the passed in timestamp object

returns.desc: A timestamp object representing the end of the month

parseTime.desc: Parses the passed in value and returns the number of seconds since midnight

input.desc: Value may be a Number (minutes since midnight) or String (hh:mm:ss where seconds are optional) or Object (must have keys **hour** and **minute**)

returns.desc: The number of seconds since midnight

validateTimestamp.desc: Validates the passed in date/time string (YYYY-mm-dd hh:mm:ss)

input.desc: A date/time string in the form `YYYY-mm-dd hh:mm:ss` (seconds are optional)

returns.desc: True if the passed in date/time string is of correct form

parsed.desc: Parses a date/time string to a simple timestamp object. For a more complete timestamp, use parseTimestamp

input.desc: A date/time string in the form `YYYY-mm-dd hh:mm:ss` (seconds are optional)

returns.desc: A timestamp object based on the passed in input. Returns 'null' on error

parseTimestamp.desc: Parses a date/time string to the timestamp object. Very similar to the `parsed` method, except also updates timestamp with formatted and relative information

input.desc: A date/time string in the form `YYYY-mm-dd hh:mm:ss` (seconds are optional)

returns.desc: A timestamp object based on the passed in input. Returns 'null' on error

parseDate.desc: Parses a JavaScript Date object to the timestamp object

returns.desc: A formatted timestamp object based on the passed in input (see updateFormatted)

makeDate.desc: Takes a timestamp and returns a JavaScript Date with time set to 00:00

returns.desc: The returned value is a JavaScript Date

makeDateTime.desc: Takes a timestamp and returns a JavaScript Date

returns.desc: The returned value is a JavaScript Date

getDayIdentifier.desc: Turns passed in timestamp object to a day identifier

returns.desc: The returned number is in the form `YYYYmmdd`

getTimeIdentifier.desc: Turns passed in timestamp object to a time identifier

returns.desc: The returned number is in the form `hhmm`

diffTimestamp.desc: Returns the number of milliseconds between the two days

strict.desc: If true, then negative values are not allowed

returns.desc: The number of milliseconds between the two timestamp objects. 0 if **strict** is true and the value would be negative

updateRelative.desc: Updates the relative information in the timestamp object. The relative information includes, compared to the **now** object, `past`, `current` and `future` booleans

now.desc: A timestamp object representing a **now** time (fixed point in time -- usually **today**)

time.desc: If true, also uses time to adjust the relative information

returns.desc: A timestamp object

updateMinutes.desc: Updates the timestamp object with the passed in minutes

minutes.desc: The number of minutes since midnight

now.desc: A timestamp object, if set, used to adjust the relative information

returns.desc: A timestamp object

updateWeekday.desc: Updates the timestamp object with the weekday information

returns.desc: A timestamp object

updateDayOfYear.desc: Updates the timestamp object with the doy (day of year) information

returns.desc: A timestamp object

updateWorkWeek.desc: Updates the timestamp object with the workweek (work week) information

returns.desc: A timestamp object

updateDisabled.desc: Updates the timestamp object to be disabled if it matches one of the items from `disabledDays`

disabledBefore.desc: A date in the form `YYYY-mm-dd` where all dates before, and including, will be disabled

disabledAfter.desc: A date in the form `YYYY-mm-dd` where all dates after, and including, will be disabled

disabledWeekdays.desc: An array of numbers representing the weekdays, where 0=Sunday to 6=Saturday

returns.desc: A timestamp object with `timestamp.disabled` true if a match was found

updateFormatted.desc: Updates the timestamp object with formatted information (`time`, `date`, `weekday`, `doy` and `workweek`)

returns.desc: A timestamp object

getDayOfYear.desc: Returns the doy (day of year) for an unformatted timestamp

returns.desc: The day of the year

getWorkWeek.desc: Returns the workweek (work week number) for an unformatted timestamp

returns.desc: The work week number of the year

getWeekday.desc: Returns the weekday (day of the week) for an unformatted timestamp

returns.desc: The week day number (0=Sunday, 1=Monday, etc)

isLeapYear.desc: Returns true if the passed in year is a leap year

year.desc: A number representing the year in YYYY format

returns.desc: Returns true if the passed in year is a leap year

daysInMonth.desc: Returns number of days in the spefified month for the specified year (takes into account leap years)

year.desc: A number representing the year in YYYY format

month.desc: A number representing the month from 0 (January) to 11 (December). For performance reasons, no checking is done to validate this value is in range. An exception will occur if it is not

returns.desc: Returns true if the passed in year is a leap year

copyTimestamp.desc: Makes a copy of the passed Timestamp

returns.desc: A copy of the passed in timestamp object

padNumber.desc: Pads the passed in number to the specfied length. Passing in `(2,2)` returns `02`

returns.desc: A padded value

getDate.desc: Returns the timestamp as a padded date

returns.desc: A date as a padded value in the form `YYYY-mm-dd`. Instead of `2020-1-2`, this function formats it as `2020-01-02`

getTime.desc: Returns the timestamp as a padded time

returns.desc: A time as a padded value in the form `hh:mm`. Instead of `2:3`, this function formats it as `02:03`

getDateTime.desc: Returns the timestamp as a padded date and time. If time is not available, then only the date will be used

returns.desc: A date and time as a padded value in the form `YYYY-mm-dd hh:mm`. Instead of `2020-1-2`, this function formats it as `2020-01-02`

nextDay.desc: Returns the timestamp set to the next day, updating month and year if needed

returns.desc: A timestamp object incremented to the next day

prevDay.desc: Returns the timestamp set to the previous day, updating month and year if needed

returns.desc: A timestamp object decremented to the next day

relativeDays.desc: Returns the timestamp set to the relative day

mover.desc: A function that handles the relative movement from one date to another. If moving backwards, use the `prevDay` method

returns.desc: A timestamp object

days.desc: The number of days to move

allowedWeekdays.desc: The allow weekdays to use. The method uses this information for allowed days

returns.desc: A timestamp object moved to the relatively specified days against the `allowedWeekdays`

moveRelativeDays.desc: Returns the timestamp set to the relative day, takes into account allowed weekdays

mover.desc: A function that handles the relative movement from one date to another. If moving backwards, use the `prevDay` method

returns.desc: A timestamp object

days.desc: The number of days to move

allowedWeekdays.desc: The allow weekdays to use. The method uses this information for allowed days

returns.desc: A timestamp object moved to the relatively specified days against the `allowedWeekdays`

findWeekday.desc: Returns the timestamp associated to the specified weekday. Use `parseTimestamp`, not `parsed` (or manually call `updateFormatted` before calling this method), so associated fields are updated correctly, otherwise this function will not work as expected.

mover.desc: A function that handles the relative movement from one date to another. If moving backwards, use the `prevDay` method

returns.desc: A timestamp object

maxDays.desc: The maxiumum number of days to move

returns.desc: A timestamp object moved to the specified days relatively against the `maxDays`

getWeekdaySkips.desc: Returns the weekday skips in an array of 0's (off) and 1's (on). Basically, can convert `[1,2,3,4,5]` to `[0,1,1,1,1,1,0]`

weekdays.desc: The normal weekdays array looks like this `[0,1,2,3,4,5,6]` where 0=Sunday, 1=Monday, etc. A week that starts on Monday, would look like this: `[1,2,3,4,5,6,0]` and a 5-day workweek would look like this: `[1,2,3,4,5]`

returns.desc: An of 7 (representing a week) of 0's (hidden) and 1's (displayed)

disabledBefore.desc: A date in the form `YYYY-mm-dd` where all dates before, and including, will be disabled

disabledAfter.desc: A date in the form `YYYY-mm-dd` where all dates after, and including, will be disabled

disabledWeekdays.desc: An array of numbers representing the weekdays, where 0=Sunday to 6=Saturday

disabledDays.desc: An array of string dates in the form `YYYY-mm-dd` that representing disabled days

max.desc: Maximum days required. 42 is the number of days in a full calendar (6 rows) month

returns.desc: An array of timestamp objects for all days that meet the criteria

timestamp.desc: A timestamp object representing the day for the intervals

minutes.desc: The number of minutes in an interval

now.desc: A timestamp object that represents 'today' or a specified point in time

returns.desc: A array of interval objects (timestamps with time) that meet the criteria

createNativeLocaleFormatter.desc: Returns a function to be used for international date formatting purposes

local.desc: A string representing the locale to use (ie: en-us for America)

getOptions.desc: A function that passes the timestamp and a boolean

short.desc: if true, specifies to use the short version (ie: 'Monday' to be returns as 'Mon', 'January' to be returned as 'Jan', etc)

returns.desc: This uses the Intl.DateTimeFormat function of the browser. Options are specified [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/DateTimeFormat)
The output of the operation

validateNumber.desc: Validates that input is a number

returns.desc: true if a number, otherwise false

isBetweenDates.desc: Checks passed timestamp is between start and end timestamps

startTimestamp.desc: The starting timestamp object to use for the comparison

endTimestamp.desc: The ending timestamp object to use for the comparison

returns.desc: true if a date is between the start and end dates

isOverlappingDates.desc: Checks passed start and end timestamps overlap the first and last timestamps. This method can be used to find if an event, with start and end dates overlap a range, like a week

startTimestamp.desc: The starting timestamp object to use for the comparison

endTimestamp.desc: The ending timestamp object to use for the comparison

firstTimestamp.desc: The first timestamp object to use for the comparison (typically the first day in a week)

lastTimestamp.desc: The last timestamp object to use for the comparison (typically the last day in a week)

returns.desc: true if the start and end timestamps overlap the first and last timestamps

daysBetween.desc: Returns the number days between two timestamps

startTimestamp.desc: The starting timestamp object to use for the comparison

endTimestamp.desc: The ending timestamp object to use for the comparison

returns.desc: The number of days beween the two timestamps

weeksBetween.desc: Returns the number weeks between two timestamps

startTimestamp.desc: The starting timestamp object to use for the comparison

endTimestamp.desc: The ending timestamp object to use for the comparison

returns.desc: The number of weeks beween the two timestamps

addToDate.desc: Takes a timestamp and increments/decrements based on options

options.desc: The options passed to the method. All items are optional and can be positive or negative

year.desc: [Optional] The amount to increment/decrement the year

month.desc: [Optional] The amount to increment/decrement the month

day.desc: [Optional] The amount to increment/decrement the day

hour.desc: [Optional] The amount to increment/decrement the hour

minute.desc: [Optional] The amount to increment/decrement the minute

returns.desc: A copy of the modified timestamp object with the applied options
